results.title: Kodak Movie Light and two bulbs
results.brief_description: “Kodak Movie light 220 x 140V 1000W V/XS/200 label on reverse says: do not earth. double insulation. On and Off switch: 250V A.C. only. ELMACO Australian plug: Peaston, 250V 7.5A V/A50/1 Two - Philips Photolita bulbs in their original boxes. Photolita* trademark PF218E 43 Photolita - NM 250V 500W C8 Made in Holland With one instruction pamphlet which has guide numbers of the exposure times.”

results.title: Eumig Wien Type P8 Electrical Projector in box
results.brief_description:
Boxed Projector Eumig Wien Type P8 electrical projector Housed in Vinyl bound box. Green felt covered board/lid for inside box. This board has a leather tab which helps to lift the board up. The top metal handle on the projector can be clicked in to stay up, or it can be pushed down. The feet at the front are adjustable and allow for a tilting adjustment. Lens: Coated Eupro F1.6 25mm lens The machine must be opened to erect the spool arms. Brown power cord with a Eumig logo. Australian power plug (Ring grip, 10 AMP, 250 V, Made in Australia) English instruction manual enclosed. Eumig metal spool housed in original cardboard box. Made in Austria.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 175mm diameter x 13mm depth Kelvin clear plastic spool. Made in Australia.

Reel capacity: 120m / 400ft diameter: 177mm diameter x 14mm depth yellow piece of card ribbon inside.

2 identical Philips projection lamps in their original boxes with double sided instructions. The lamp inside the box is packaged between two pieces of corrugated cardboard. 7238N / 05 12V 100W B15S A8 Made in Germany

Broken brush made from real hair. Made in Japan. (used for cleaning?)

results.title: Vitaphone Disc: Columbia Pictures Corporation, "Wall Street", CP-B26 Reel Two, Times Played 15
results.brief_description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.

results.title: The Brown Box replica
results.brief_description:
The Brown Box was reproduced for the Renewal project - facilitated by Mark Baer (Trustee of the Ralph Baer Trust). This object is in working condition tested by Mark Baer 2 November 2019.

Text from Arieh Offman, Curator, Videogames, ACMI - “The Brown Box prototype, created and patented by Ralph Baer, was the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey (currently held by ACMI), and development began in 1966. It was originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’ and received its better known name ‘Brown Box’ from the faux wood grain self-adhesive vinyl that was attached to the prototype to make it more attractive to potential investor. The game unit could play multiple programs / games, and this was achieved by flipping the physical switches on the front of the unit – these included games such as ping pong, checkers, and four different sports games. The Brown Box was the seventh version of this prototype, with multiple versions coming before and after it with alterations to hardware and output.”

Description from the Smithsonian Museum:
“This machine paved the way for the video games of today.
In 1967, Ralph Baer and his colleagues at Sanders Associates, Inc. developed a prototype for the first multiplayer, multiprogram video game system. Since Sanders hoped to license the technology for a commercial venture, Baer understood that the games had to be fun or investors and consumers would not be interested. In an oral history interview (copies available in the Archives Center at the National Museum of American History), Ralph Baer recalled, “The minute we played ping-pong, we knew we had a product. Before that we weren’t too sure.”Originally called TV Game Unit #7, much like the “Pump Unit” before it, it became far better known by its nickname, “The Brown Box.” The name comes from the brown wood-grain, self-adhesive vinyl used to make the prototype look more attractive to potential investors. The “Brown Box,” though only a prototype, had basic features that most video games consoles still have today: two controls and a multigame program system.The “Brown Box” could be programmed to play a variety of games by flipping the switches along the front of the unit, as can be seen in the picture. Program cards were used to show which switches needed to be set for specific games. “Brown Box” games included ping-pong, checkers, four different sports games, target shooting with the use of a lightgun and a golf putting game, which required the use of a special attachment. Sanders licensed the “Brown Box” to Magnavox, which released the system as the Magnavox Odyssey in 1972.” https://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1301997
results.description:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.
description_for_label:
In 1966, the father of videogames, Ralph Baer, began developing the Brown Box prototype, the forerunner to the first home console ever released, the Magnavox Odyssey.

Originally called the ‘TV Game Unit #7’, Baer’s prototype became better known as the Brown Box because of its faux wood-grain vinyl. It ran multiple programs and games – including ping-pong, checkers and four different sports games – which were controlled by flipping the switches on the front of the unit.

results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
